20110114180558.000|20110114180601.000|TR0|    BRUCK:  Well, it's like any case.  You 
20110114180601.000|20110114180603.000|TR0|know, you begin with a terrible crime or 
20110114180603.000|20110114180606.000|TR0|-- that has blighted lives and rant the 
20110114180606.000|20110114180608.000|TR0|whole community, you have to stay focused 
20110114180608.000|20110114180611.000|TR0|on that and not have blinders and not see 
20110114180611.000|20110114180613.000|TR0|the damage and the harm that your client 
20110114180613.000|20110114180616.000|TR0|has apparently committed.  But, at the 
20110114180616.000|20110114180618.000|TR0|same time, you have to go to work and find 
20110114180618.000|20110114180621.000|TR0|every witness and every scrap of records 
20110114180621.000|20110114180623.000|TR0|and evidence that might explain your 
20110114180623.000|20110114180626.000|TR0|clients path in life and who he is, and 
20110114180626.000|20110114180628.000|TR0|why it's come to this.
20110114180628.000|20110114180631.000|TR0|
20110114180631.000|20110114180633.000|TR0|And, often times, the first appearances of 
20110114180633.000|20110114180636.000|TR0|things prove to be deceiving and the real 
20110114180636.000|20110114180639.000|TR0|story can be quite different than the way 
20110114180639.000|20110114180641.000|TR0|it may have appeared at first.
20110114180641.000|20110114180644.000|TR0|
20110114180644.000|20110114180646.000|TR0|This may be a story involving severe 
20110114180646.000|20110114180649.000|TR0|mental illness.  If it is, of course, that 
20110114180649.000|20110114180651.000|TR0|is something that none of us choose.  And 
20110114180651.000|20110114180654.000|TR0|severe mental illness is not something 
20110114180654.000|20110114180656.000|TR0|that you decide to do.  It's something 
20110114180656.000|20110114180659.000|TR0|that happens to you, or that can happen to 
20110114180659.000|20110114180701.000|TR0|anyone or to any of our children, and 
20110114180701.000|20110114180704.000|TR0|that's a realization that it's the job of

20110114181102.000|20110114181105.000|TR0|going to stay with me.  It was so 
20110114181105.000|20110114181107.000|TR0|incredibly important. I didn't know what 
20110114181107.000|20110114181110.000|TR0|was going on.  I did know that Gabby and 
20110114181110.000|20110114181112.000|TR0|Ron were down.  I didn't know anything 
20110114181112.000|20110114181115.000|TR0|else, and I was not aware of what the 
20110114181115.000|20110114181117.000|TR0|gunman was doing so I just played dead.
20110114181117.000|20110114181120.000|TR0|
20110114181120.000|20110114181122.000|TR0|And, then, after that, Bob touched my 
20110114181122.000|20110114181125.000|TR0|shoulder and stayed with me, made cell 
20110114181125.000|20110114181128.000|TR0|phone call to Bruce.  I told him to 
20110114181128.000|20110114181130.000|TR0|downplay it.  I didn't want Bruce to be

20110114181135.000|20110114181138.000|TR0|cell phone back to him.  And I cannot tell

20110114181654.000|20110114181657.000|TR0|VELSHI:  Remember these scenes from 2005, 
20110114181657.000|20110114181659.000|TR0|April, the funeral of Pope John Paul II.  
20110114181659.000|20110114181702.000|TR0|The banners say "santo subito," which 
20110114181702.000|20110114181704.000|TR0|means sainthood now.  Well, now has not 
20110114181704.000|20110114181707.000|TR0|arrived, but it's closer than ever.
20110114181707.000|20110114181709.000|TR0|
20110114181709.000|20110114181712.000|TR0|Less than six years after he died, John 
20110114181712.000|20110114181714.000|TR0|Paul II is being officially credited with 
20110114181714.000|20110114181717.000|TR0|a miraculous healing and the Vatican says 
20110114181717.000|20110114181719.000|TR0|he'll be beatified the week after Easter.  
20110114181719.000|20110114181722.000|TR0|That's the half way point to sainthood.  
20110114181722.000|20110114181724.000|TR0|Keep in mind, this process generally takes 
20110114181724.000|20110114181727.000|TR0|decades, in some cases it's taken 
20110114181727.000|20110114181729.000|TR0|centuries.
20110114181729.000|20110114181732.000|TR0|
20110114181732.000|20110114181734.000|TR0|But John Paul II broke the mold in lots of 
20110114181734.000|20110114181737.000|TR0|ways.  He was the first non-Italian pope 
20110114181737.000|20110114181739.000|TR0|in 455 years.  In his 26 and a half years 
20110114181739.000|20110114181742.000|TR0|as the leader of the Roman Catholic 
20110114181742.000|20110114181744.000|TR0|Church, he visited 129 countries. And he, 
20110114181744.000|20110114181747.000|TR0|himself, canonized 482 saints, more than 
20110114181747.000|20110114181749.000|TR0|all his predecessors combined.
20110114181749.000|20110114181752.000|TR0|
20110114181752.000|20110114181755.000|TR0|Want to talk more about the man, the 
20110114181755.000|20110114181757.000|TR0|miracle, and the process that the catholic 
20110114181757.000|20110114181800.000|TR0|church goes through of recognizing saints 
20110114181800.000|20110114181802.000|TR0|with John Allen.  He's a familiar face to 
20110114181802.000|20110114181805.000|TR0|us.  He's our senior Vatican analyst and a

20110114181812.000|20110114181815.000|TR0|Revolutionizing The Catholic Church."
20110114181815.000|20110114181817.000|TR0|
20110114181817.000|20110114181820.000|TR0|John, good to see you.  Thanks for being 
20110114181820.000|20110114181822.000|TR0|with us.
20110114181822.000|20110114181825.000|TR0|
20110114181825.000|20110114181827.000|TR0|First of all, let's talk about the 
20110114181827.000|20110114181830.000|TR0|supposed miracle.
20110114181830.000|20110114181832.000|TR0|
20110114181832.000|20110114181835.000|TR0|JOHN ALLEN, CNN SENIOR VATICAN ANALYST:  
20110114181835.000|20110114181837.000|TR0|Well, the miracle in this case involves 
20110114181837.000|20110114181840.000|TR0|the healing of a 49-year-old French nun 
20110114181840.000|20110114181842.000|TR0|from an aggressive form of Parkinson's 
20110114181842.000|20110114181845.000|TR0|disease.  And, of course, Ali, there's 
20110114181845.000|20110114181847.000|TR0|kind of a nice poetic arc to that because 
20110114181847.000|20110114181850.000|TR0|John Paul II himself suffered from 
20110114181850.000|20110114181852.000|TR0|Parkinson's.
20110114181852.000|20110114181855.000|TR0|
20110114181855.000|20110114181857.000|TR0|The report is that shortly after the 
20110114181857.000|20110114181900.000|TR0|pope's death, in April 2005, the religious 
20110114181900.000|20110114181902.000|TR0|order to which this nun belongs began 
20110114181902.000|20110114181905.000|TR0|praying to John Paul II.  Apparently she 
20110114181905.000|20110114181907.000|TR0|wrote the late pope's name on a prayer 
20110114181907.000|20110114181910.000|TR0|card and tucked it under her mattress one 
20110114181910.000|20110114181912.000|TR0|night, woke up the next morning completely 
20110114181912.000|20110114181915.000|TR0|cured from the Parkinson's and went back 
20110114181915.000|20110114181917.000|TR0|to her normal work as a maternity nurse.
20110114181917.000|20110114181920.000|TR0|
20110114181920.000|20110114181922.000|TR0|The Vatican standards for a healing to be 
20110114181922.000|20110114181925.000|TR0|considered miraculous are that it has to 
20110114181925.000|20110114181927.000|TR0|be instantaneous, it has to be complete, 
20110114181927.000|20110114181930.000|TR0|it has to be permanent.  There's a bank of 
20110114181930.000|20110114181933.000|TR0|doctors, then a bank of theologians, then 
20110114181933.000|20110114181935.000|TR0|a group of cardinals and bishops and then 
20110114181935.000|20110114181938.000|TR0|finally the pope himself who would have to 
20110114181938.000|20110114181940.000|TR0|sign off.  And, in this case, they 
20110114181940.000|20110114181943.000|TR0|obviously all agreed that this was the 
20110114181943.000|20110114181945.000|TR0|real deal.       VELSHI:  Let's talk about 
20110114181945.000|20110114181948.000|TR0|the process of becoming a saint.  Tell me 
20110114181948.000|20110114181950.000|TR0|a bit about it and the fact that Pope John 
20110114181950.000|20110114181953.000|TR0|Paul II actually changed the process 
20110114181953.000|20110114181955.000|TR0|himself.
20110114181955.000|20110114181958.000|TR0|
20110114181958.000|20110114182000.000|TR0|ALLEN:  Yes.  When John Paul II revised 
20110114182000.000|20110114182003.000|TR0|the law of the catholic church in 1983, 
20110114182003.000|20110114182005.000|TR0|one of the things that was affected was 
20110114182005.000|20110114182008.000|TR0|the sainthood process.  A number of things 
20110114182008.000|20110114182010.000|TR0|changed, but I think the bottom line was 
20110114182010.000|20110114182013.000|TR0|that the pope wanted to, in some ways, 
20110114182013.000|20110114182015.000|TR0|accelerate the process because he believed 
20110114182015.000|20110114182018.000|TR0|that there were a number of great saints 
20110114182018.000|20110114182020.000|TR0|of the 20th century, including martyrs 
20110114182020.000|20110114182023.000|TR0|under the Nazis and martyrs under the 
20110114182023.000|20110114182025.000|TR0|communists and so on, that he wanted to be 
20110114182025.000|20110114182028.000|TR0|able to hold up to the world.
20110114182028.000|20110114182030.000|TR0|
20110114182030.000|20110114182033.000|TR0|The effect of that has been that it has 
20110114182033.000|20110114182035.000|TR0|made it easier, when you have a case that 
20110114182035.000|20110114182038.000|TR0|you want to move through the system fairly 
20110114182038.000|20110114182040.000|TR0|quickly to get it done.  That was the 
20110114182040.000|20110114182043.000|TR0|case, of course, with Mother Teresa, who 
20110114182043.000|20110114182045.000|TR0|was beatified in 2003, just six years 
20110114182045.000|20110114182048.000|TR0|after her death.  And it is now, of 
20110114182048.000|20110114182050.000|TR0|course, again the case here with John Paul 
20110114182050.000|20110114182053.000|TR0|II once again moving from soup to nuts in 
20110114182053.000|20110114182055.000|TR0|a period of just six years.
20110114182055.000|20110114182058.000|TR0|
20110114182058.000|20110114182100.000|TR0|VELSHI:  And, real quick, Pope Benedict 
20110114182100.000|20110114182103.000|TR0|did actually change something as well.  He 
20110114182103.000|20110114182106.000|TR0|made the waiting period shorter?
20110114182106.000|20110114182108.000|TR0|
20110114182108.000|20110114182111.000|TR0|ALLEN:  Yes.  I mean, normally speaking, 
20110114182111.000|20110114182113.000|TR0|five years have to elapse between the 
20110114182113.000|20110114182116.000|TR0|death of a person and the beginning of a 
20110114182116.000|20110114182118.000|TR0|sainthood clause.  But, of course, you 
20110114182118.000|20110114182121.000|TR0|know, under the rubric of, it's good to be 
20110114182121.000|20110114182123.000|TR0|pope, the pope can set that aside if he 
20110114182123.000|20110114182126.000|TR0|chooses and, in this case, he chose to do 
20110114182126.000|20110114182128.000|TR0|that in response to grassroots demand.  
20110114182128.000|20110114182131.000|TR0|And you showed those images from the 
20110114182131.000|20110114182133.000|TR0|funeral mass, the chants of "santo subito."
20110114182133.000|20110114182136.000|TR0|
20110114182136.000|20110114182138.000|TR0|Also in response to the fact that during 
20110114182138.000|20110114182141.000|TR0|the concave that elected Benedict to be 
20110114182141.000|20110114182143.000|TR0|pope, the cardinals actually signed a 
20110114182143.000|20110114182146.000|TR0|petition requesting that whoever the next 
20110114182146.000|20110114182148.000|TR0|pope would be would move up the process.  
20110114182148.000|20110114182151.000|TR0|And so Benedict, obviously, did that and 
20110114182151.000|20110114182153.000|TR0|here we are today.
20110114182153.000|20110114182156.000|TR0|
20110114182156.000|20110114182158.000|TR0|VELSHI:  All right.  Good conversation 
20110114182158.000|20110114182201.000|TR0|with you, as always, John. Thanks for 
20110114182201.000|20110114182203.000|TR0|being with us and telling us more about 
20110114182203.000|20110114182206.000|TR0|this.
20110114182206.000|20110114182208.000|TR0|

20110114185025.000|20110114185027.000|TR0|designs an object on a computer and then 
20110114185027.000|20110114185030.000|TR0|sends that design to a 3-D printer.  The 
20110114185030.000|20110114185032.000|TR0|printer does not draw a picture of the

20110114185035.000|20110114185037.000|TR0|printer would do.  Instead, it physically

20110114185040.000|20110114185042.000|TR0|plastic out of nozzles.  The plastic

20110114185045.000|20110114185047.000|TR0|layer the printer actually constructs the

20110114185549.000|20110114185551.000|TR0|bringing it to the market.  Bre Pettis is
